citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One grey female adult chinchilla has a significant medical issue that had not been identified by the licensee prior to the
inspection. On the right side of the chinchilla’s neck there is an approximately 1/2 inch diameter round area of matted hair
and yellow/brown material. In the center, there is yellow fluid. The surrounding hair is wet and there is patchy hair loss
around the affected area. The licensee stated that he had not observed this medical issue before the inspection. Daily
observation of animals is essential for identifying and promptly treating issues affecting their health and wellbeing.
Yellow/brown material and matted hair may be a sign of infection, which can cause pain, stress, and could spread to
affect other areas of the body. Correct by today, August 16, 2023 at 6PM by having the animal evaluated by a veterinarian
and following the veterinarian’s instructions for treatment, monitoring, and follow up.

One grey adult male lionhead rabbit did not have adequate water. The rabbit’s only source of drinking water was a water
bottle, which was empty. When the water bottle was filled, the rabbit drank eagerly and continuously for 90 seconds, after
which it stopped and took a few more drinks intermittently over the following 5 minutes. Once filled, the water began
leaking, and the licensee fixed the leak. The licensee stated that the rabbit water bottle had been filled the night before.
Rabbits without adequate access to drinking water may suffer from thirst, dehydration, poor circulation, and gut/digestion
problems. Correct by today, August 16, 2023, at 3:30PM Central Time by providing this and all other rabbits with
adequate access to drinking water. Corrected at the time of the inspection.

The outdoor enclosure housing one female weeper capuchin has a gap beneath the bottom of one of the walls where the
animal has been digging. The gap is approximately 6 inches long and nearby another gap is approximately 2 inches long.
The wall is not attached to a footer or wire floor. Enclosures for primates must be maintained in good repair so that
animals cannot escape or become entrapped or injured. Correct by August 30, 2023 by repairing this enclosure and
maintaining all primates in enclosures that are safe and in good repair.

The outdoor enclosure housing two adult coatis has a gap beneath the bottom of one of the walls where the animals have
been digging. The gap is approximately 4 feet long. The wall is not attached to a footer or wire floor. Enclosures for
animals must be maintained in good repair so that animals cannot escape or become entrapped or injured. Correct by
August 30, 2023 by repairing this enclosure and maintaining all animals in enclosures that are safe and in good repair.

The perimeter fence is not 6-feet tall in some areas.
***There is a short (approximately 4-foot-tall) gate in the perimeter fence which leads from an area near some primates
and coati's into a paddock containing llama and sheep.
***There is a section of perimeter fence located at the bottom of the paddock containing petting zoo sheep and goats
which is approximately 4-feet-tall. The licensee stated that this area of fence was damaged by a recent storm.
***The perimeter fence includes the main barn building, whose doors are left open during the day, creating a gap in the
fence. The licensee stated that the doors of barn are not always closed at night when the weather is hot, creating an
opening in the perimeter fence that is unattended overnight.
A perimeter fence is required to prevent unauthorized entry of people and animals which could steal, injure, sicken,
harass, or kill the captive animals. Exotic animals such as these, housed in outdoor facilities, require a 6-foot-tall
perimeter fence around their enclosures.
Correct by ensuring that a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence is maintained around the exotic animal enclosures of sufficient
strength to prevent entry of unauthorized people or animals. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the
APHIS Administrator. A perimeter fence must also be maintained around outdoor primate enclosures as required under
3.78(d).
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the owner.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One grey female adult chinchilla has a significant medical issue that had not been identified by the licensee prior to the

affect other areas of the body. Correct by today, August 16, 2023 at 6PM by having the animal evaluated by a veterinarian

3.55  Direct
   
Watering. 
One grey adult male lionhead rabbit did not have adequate water. The rabbit’s only source of drinking water was a water

3.80(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The outdoor enclosure housing one female weeper capuchin has a gap beneath the bottom of one of the walls where the 
animal has been digging. The gap is approximately 6 inches long and nearby another gap is approximately 2 inches long. 
The wall is not attached to a footer or wire floor. Enclosures for primates must be maintained in good repair so that 
animals cannot escape or become entrapped or injured. Correct by August 30, 2023 by repairing this enclosure and 
maintaining all primates in enclosures that are safe and in good repair. 
3.125(a)

Facilities, general. 
The outdoor enclosure housing two adult coatis has a gap beneath the bottom of one of the walls where the animals have 
been digging. The gap is approximately 4 feet long. The wall is not attached to a footer or wire floor. Enclosures for 
animals must be maintained in good repair so that animals cannot escape or become entrapped or injured. Correct by 
August 30, 2023 by repairing this enclosure and maintaining all animals in enclosures that are safe and in good repair. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fence is not 6-feet tall in some areas.  
***There is a short (approximately 4-foot-tall) gate in the perimeter fence which leads from an area near some primates 
and coati's into a paddock containing llama and sheep.  
***There is a section of perimeter fence located at the bottom of the paddock containing petting zoo sheep and goats 
which is approximately 4-feet-tall. The licensee stated that this area of fence was damaged by a recent storm.  
***The perimeter fence includes the main barn building, whose doors are left open during the day, creating a gap in the 
fence. The licensee stated that the doors of barn are not always closed at night when the weather is hot, creating an 
opening in the perimeter fence that is unattended overnight. 
A perimeter fence is required to prevent unauthorized entry of people and animals which could steal, injure, sicken, 
harass, or kill the captive animals. Exotic animals such as these, housed in outdoor facilities, require a 6-foot-tall 
perimeter fence around their enclosures. 
Correct by ensuring that a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence is maintained around the exotic animal enclosures of sufficient 
strength to prevent entry of unauthorized people or animals. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the 
APHIS Administrator. A perimeter fence must also be maintained around outdoor primate enclosures as required under 
3.78(d). 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the owner.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
